and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f n = 2 * f (n-1) + 2"
shows  "f 100 = 2 powr 100 - 2"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Consider the triangular array of numbers with 0, 1, 2, 3, $\dots$ along the sides and interior numbers obtained by adding the two adjacent numbers in the previous row.  Rows 1 through 6 are shown.

\[
\begin{array}{ccccccccccc}
& & & & & 0 & & & & & \\
& & & & 1 & & 1 & & & & \\
& & & 2 & & 2 & & 2 & & & \\
& & 3 & & 4 & & 4 & & 3 & & \\
& 4 & & 7 & & 8 & & 7 & & 4 & \\
5 & & 11 & & 15 & & 15 & & 11 & & 5
\end{array}
\]Find the sum of the numbers in the 100th row.  Your answer should use exponential notation, in simplest form. The final Answer is 2^{100} - 2
 ### Proof
 Let $f(n)$ denote the sum of the numbers in the $n$th row.
 We start by looking at an example. Suppose we take the 5th row, make a copy of every number, and send each copy to the fifth row. [asy] unitsize (1 cm); pair A, B; int i; for (i = 1; i <= 5; ++i) {   A = (2*i - 1,1);
 	B = (2*i - 2,0); 	draw(interp(A,B,0.2)--interp(A,B,0.7),Arrow(6)); 	A = (2*i - 1,1); 	B = (2*i,0); 	draw(interp(A,B,0.2)--interp(A,B,0.7),Arrow(6)); } label("$4$", (1,1)); label("$7$", (3,1)); label("$8$", (5,1));
 label("$7$", (7,1)); label("$4$", (9,1)); label("$4$", (0,0)); label("$4 + 7$", (2,0)); label("$7 + 8$", (4,0)); label("$8 + 7$", (6,0)); label("$7 + 4$", (8,0)); label("$4$", (10,0)); [/asy] Currently, the sum of the numbers in the fifth row is exactly double the sum of the numbers in the fourth row, because it contains two copies of every number in the fourth row.
 To make it look like the fifth row in the actual triangle, all we must do is add 1 to the first and last numbers in the row.
 Thus, $f(5) = 2f(4) + 2.$ More generally, \[f(n) = 2f(n - 1) + 2\]for any $n \ge 2.$
 Let $g(n) = f(n) + 2.$  Then $f(n) = g(n) - 2,$ so \[g(n) - 2 = 2(g(n - 1) - 2) + 2.\]This simplifies to $g(n) = 2g(n - 1).$  Since $g(1) = 2,$ it follows that $g(n) = 2^n.$  Then $f(n) = 2^n - 2.$  In particular, $f(100) = \boxed{2^{100} - 2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f 0 = 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f n = 2 * f (n-1) + 2"
shows  "f 100 = 2 powr 100 - 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A function $f(n)$ is defined as follows: $f(0) = 0$ and $f(n) = 2 * f(n-1) + 2$ for all natural numbers $n \geq 1$. What is the value of $f(100)$? The final answer is $2^{100} - 2$.

theorem
fixes n :: nat and arr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "arr 1 1 = 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> i \<in> {2..n}. arr i 1 = arr (i-1) 1 + 1"
and h2 : "\<forall> i \<in> {2..n}. \<forall> j \<in> {2..i}. arr i j = arr (i-1) (j-1) + arr (i-1) j"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> j. arr 100 j) {1..100} = 2 powr 100 - 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Suppose you have an array where the first element is 0, and each subsequent element in the first column is the increment of the previous element by 1. Also, each element in the rest of the array is the sum of the element above it and the element to the upper left. Find the sum of the elements in the 100th row. The final answer is $2^{100} - 2$.
